segment.source: 4779(S) A session was disconnected from a Window Station.
segment.target: 4779(S) A session was disconnected from a Window Station.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4779(S) A session was disconnected from a Window Station.
segment.target: Describes security event 4779(S) A session was disconnected from a Window Station.

segment.source: 4779(S): A session was disconnected from a Window Station.
segment.target: 4779(S): A session was disconnected from a Window Station.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event is generated when a user disconnects from an existing Terminal Services session, or when a user switches away from an existing desktop using Fast User Switching.
segment.target: This event is generated when a user disconnects from an existing Terminal Services session, or when a user switches away from an existing desktop using Fast User Switching.

segment.source: This event also generated when user disconnects from virtual host Hyper-V Enhanced Session, for example.
segment.target: This event also generated when user disconnects from virtual host Hyper-V Enhanced Session, for example.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account for which the session was disconnected.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account for which the session was disconnected.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Session:
segment.target: Session:

segment.source: Session Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of disconnected session.
segment.target: Session Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of disconnected session.

segment.source: Examples:
segment.target: Examples:

segment.source: RDP-RcpN, where N is a number of session – typical RDP session name.
segment.target: RDP-RcpN, where N is a number of session – typical RDP session name.

segment.source: Console – console session, typical for Fast User Switching.
segment.target: Console – console session, typical for Fast User Switching.

segment.source: 31C5CE94259D4006A9E43 – example of “Hyper-V Enhanced Session” session name.
segment.target: 31C5CE94259D4006A9E43 – example of “Hyper-V Enhanced Session” session name.

segment.source: You can see the list of current session’s using “query session” command in command prompt.
segment.target: You can see the list of current session’s using “query session” command in command prompt.

segment.source: Example of output (see SESSIONNAME column):
segment.target: Example of output (see SESSIONNAME column):

segment.source: Additional Information:
segment.target: Additional Information:

segment.source: Client Name Type = UnicodeString: machine name from which the session was disconnected.
segment.target: Client Name Type = UnicodeString: machine name from which the session was disconnected.

segment.source: Has “Unknown” value for console session.
segment.target: Has “Unknown” value for console session.

segment.source: Client Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of the computer from which the session was disconnected.
segment.target: Client Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of the computer from which the session was disconnected.

segment.source: IPv6 address or ::ffff:IPv4 address of a client.
segment.target: IPv6 address or ::ffff:IPv4 address of a client.

segment.source: ::1 or 127.0.0.1 means localhost.
segment.target: ::1 or 127.0.0.1 means localhost.

segment.source: Has “LOCAL” value for console session.
segment.target: Has “LOCAL” value for console session.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4779(S): A session was disconnected from a Window Station.
segment.target: For 4779(S): A session was disconnected from a Window Station.

segment.source: Type of monitoring required
segment.target: Type of monitoring required

segment.source: Recommendation
segment.target: Recommendation

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectAccount Name” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectAccount Name” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectAccount Name” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectAccount Name” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectAccount Name” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectAccount Name” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectAccount Name” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectAccount Name” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.
segment.target: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “SubjectAccount Name” to see whether the account type is as expected.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “SubjectAccount Name” to see whether the account type is as expected.

segment.source: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).
segment.target: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).

segment.source: Monitor this event for the “SubjectAccount Domain” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event for the “SubjectAccount Domain” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.

segment.source: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should not typically perform any actions.
segment.target: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should not typically perform any actions.

segment.source: For example, you might have computers to which connections should not be made from certain accounts or addresses.
segment.target: For example, you might have computers to which connections should not be made from certain accounts or addresses.

segment.source: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectAccount Name” that you are concerned about.
segment.target: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectAccount Name” that you are concerned about.

segment.source: If you have a target Computer: (or other target device) to which connections should not be made from certain accounts or addresses, monitor this event for the corresponding Client Name or Client Address.
segment.target: If you have a target Computer: (or other target device) to which connections should not be made from certain accounts or addresses, monitor this event for the corresponding Client Name or Client Address.

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.

segment.source: If Fast User Switching is disabled on workstations or specific computers, then monitor for any event with Session Name = Console.
segment.target: If Fast User Switching is disabled on workstations or specific computers, then monitor for any event with Session Name = Console.

segment.source: If Remote Desktop Connections are not allowed for specific users (SubjectAccount Name) or disabled on some computers, then monitor for Session Name = RDP-Tcp (substring).
segment.target: If Remote Desktop Connections are not allowed for specific users (SubjectAccount Name) or disabled on some computers, then monitor for Session Name = RDP-Tcp (substring).

segment.source: To ensure that connections are made only from your internal IP address list, monitor the Additional InformationClient Address in this event.
segment.target: To ensure that connections are made only from your internal IP address list, monitor the Additional InformationClient Address in this event.
